segment.source: 4908(S) Special Groups Logon table modified.
segment.target: 4908(S) Special Groups Logon table modified.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4908(S) Special Groups Logon table modified.
segment.target: Describes security event 4908(S) Special Groups Logon table modified.

segment.source: 4908(S): Special Groups Logon table modified.
segment.target: 4908(S): Special Groups Logon table modified.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time Special Groups logon table was modified.
segment.target: This event generates every time Special Groups logon table was modified.

segment.source: This event also generates during system startup.
segment.target: This event also generates during system startup.

segment.source: This event is always logged regardless of the "Audit Policy Change" sub-category setting.
segment.target: This event is always logged regardless of the "Audit Policy Change" sub-category setting.

segment.source: More information about Special Groups auditing can be found here:
segment.target: More information about Special Groups auditing can be found here:

segment.source: http://blogs.technet.com/b/askds/archive/2008/03/11/special-groups-auditing-via-group-policy-preferences.aspx
segment.target: http://blogs.technet.com/b/askds/archive/2008/03/11/special-groups-auditing-via-group-policy-preferences.aspx

segment.source: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/947223
segment.target: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/947223

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Special Groups Type = UnicodeString: contains current list of SIDs (groups or accounts) which are members of Special Groups.
segment.target: Special Groups Type = UnicodeString: contains current list of SIDs (groups or accounts) which are members of Special Groups.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: “HKEYLOCALMACHINESYSTEMControlSet001ControlLsaAuditSpecialGroups” registry value contains current list of SIDs which are included in Special Groups:
segment.target: “HKEYLOCALMACHINESYSTEMControlSet001ControlLsaAuditSpecialGroups” registry value contains current list of SIDs which are included in Special Groups:

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4908(S): Special Groups Logon table modified.
segment.target: For 4908(S): Special Groups Logon table modified.

segment.source: If you use the Special Groups feature, then this event should be always monitored, especially on high value assets or computers.
segment.target: If you use the Special Groups feature, then this event should be always monitored, especially on high value assets or computers.

segment.source: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.
segment.target: If this change was not planned, investigate the reason for the change.

segment.source: If you don’t use the Special Groups feature, then this event should be always monitored because it indicates use of the Special Groups feature outside of your standard procedures.
segment.target: If you don’t use the Special Groups feature, then this event should be always monitored because it indicates use of the Special Groups feature outside of your standard procedures.
